metadata.title: Diguetinus raptator Roewer 1912
metadata.description:
Diguetinus raptator Roewer, 1912

(Figs 1A, B, E; 2A, B; 3A, B; 6 A-F; 7A-C; 8-9)

Diguetinus raptator Roewer, 1912: 271, pl. 1 fig. 25; 1923: 863, fig. 1030; 1956: 252. — Bronn 1932: 7, fig. 9b. — Di Caporiacco 1938: 280. — Goodnight & Goodnight 1942a: 15. — Weidner 1959: 121. — Cokendolpher & Lee 1993: 16. — Crawford 1992: 17. — Kury & Cokendolpher 2000: 150; 2020: 52. — Cokendolpher et al. 2021: 119, fig. 1-9.

TYPE DATA. — See Cokendolpher et al. (2021).

MATERIAL EXAMINED. — Mexico • 6 ♂, 10 ♀; Jalisco: Guadalajara: Bosque El Centinela; 20°45’44.4”N, 103°22’51.1”W; 1584 m a.s.l.; 26.X.2023; D. Ochoa-Vázquez, O. I. Ochoa-Vázquez leg.; GenBank accession numbers: PV430733-36; CRLSM-OP _01; CNAN-OP2021.

EMENDED DIAGNOSIS. — Diguetinus raptator can be distinguished from Diguetinus spinulatus stat. restit. by the combination of the following characters: a) dorsum with transverse rows of spines running across each tergite of the opisthosoma, not in a single row (as in Diguetinus spinulatus stat. restit.) but rather with random to at least two rows of spines per tergite; b) leg femur predominantly dark brown; c) glans length less than length of alae section, about 1/2 the length of alae; d) alae section proportion approximately 1/6 of the total length of the penis; e) alae section internal texture with a reticulate pattern, dark in colour, present over the entire alae surface.

metadata.title: Diguetinus Roewer 1912
metadata.description:
Genus Diguetinus Roewer, 1912

Diguetinus Roewer, 1912: 271, pl. 1 fig. 25; 1923: 863, fig. 1030; 1956: 252. — Bronn 1932: 7, fig. 9b. — Di Caporiacco 1938: 280. — Goodnight & Goodnight 1942a: 15. — Weidner 1959: 121. — Gruber 1969: 273. — Cokendolpher 1984a: 27-28; 1984b: 377. — Cokendolpher & Cokendolpher 1984: 168. — Cokendolpher & Lee 1993: 16. — Crawford 1992: 17. — Kury & Cokendolpher 2000: 150; 2020: 52. — Cokendolpher et al. 2021: 119, fig. 1-9.

TYPE SPECIES. — Diguetinus raptator Roewer, 1912.

INCLUDED SPECIES. — Diguetinus raptator Roewer, 1912 and Diguetinus spinulatus (Banks, 1898) stat. restit.

EMENDED DIAGNOSIS. — Diguetinus can be recognized from others members of Globipedidae by the following combination of characters: a) large bodied (adult individuals dorsum length from 10 to 12.5 mm); b) dorsum with transverse rows of spines running across each opisthosomal tergite, from a single row configuration to a randomly ordered arrangement of at least two rows of spines; c) tergite spines yellowish-white and black tipped, usually with at least one chaetal sensilla present near the base of each spine, none spine extended to a height greater than the ocularium; d) stylus of the penis coiled in a complete circle.

This Zenodo record is a permanently preserved version of a PREreview. You can view the complete PREreview at https://prereview.org/reviews/17773507.

The electron is re-examined as a single electromagnetic wave that closes upon itself with a half-twist, forming a Möbius ribbon whose circumference equals one reduced Compton wavelength. This topological closure traps the invariant rest-energy and forces the field to return to its initial phase only after a 4π rotation, reproducing spin one-half without invoking abstract spinors. Adding an integer number N of radial nodes generates a standing-wave ladder where frequency and radius scale as fN = f0/(N +1) and rN = (N +1)rinner. The ladder matches the Bohr--Rydberg spectrum when n=N+1 and links the fine-structure constant to the Compton--Bohr radius ratio α = rinner/a0. We give a concrete sketch for the Schwinger anomaly from core--envelope interference and outline how point-like scattering can coexist with a finite geometric core. The geometry yields two near-term tests: an enhanced h/2e harmonic in mesoscopic Aharonov--Bohm rings (with the usual h/e present but relatively suppressed in a specific regime), and a forward-Compton form-factor minimum at a momentum transfer set by Qrinner≈ x1 with x1 the first Bessel zero (x1 ≈ 2.4048), i.e. Q ≃ 1.2 MeV/c to 1.6 MeV/c depending on the aperture kernel (ring-like J0 vs spherical sinc). We also streamline the orbital taxonomy (S,P,D,...) as emergent angular families from azimuthal node counts; the music-note analogy is offered only as a light heuristic.

Competing interests

The authors declare that they have no competing interests.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

The authors declare that they did not use generative AI to come up with new ideas for their review.

metadata.title: Pure Time Theory - Application II - Mental Disorders and Temporal Desynchronization: Derivation from the L0 Grammar
metadata.description:
This article, the second in the Applications series of Pure Time Theory (PTT), derives a theory of mental disorders as temporal desynchronizations — not as an alternative psychiatric model, but as a necessary consequence of the temporal ontology stabilized in Chapters I–IX of the Genesis.

Main results.

1. Mental disorder: a phase misalignment between the cognitive state ψ(t) ∈ H(Λ) and the stable geometry of the Book (type-1 modal mass).

2. Topologies: bipolarity (cadence oscillation), depression (gradient collapse), anxiety (anticipatory hyper-alignment), autism (rigid hyper-coherence), ADHD (modal window fragmentation), psychoses (rupture of the Qalb filter).

3. Pain and suffering: three levels — pain (desynchronization signal from type-2 biological oscillators), psychic suffering (misalignment perceived via the ʿAql, shared by animals and humans), and existential suffering (amplified by the Qalb, specific to humans).

4. Healing: phase realignment via acceptance (reduction of added tension), then the scalar stabilizers (love, stillness, presence) — not symptom suppression.

5. Genetics/Epigenetics: the genome configures access (window Mₙ), epigenetics dynamically modulates this access; animal instinct as empirical evidence.

6. Pharmacological validation: effective psychotropics converge toward modulation of Layer 1 parameters (ρω, Mₙ, Wconn) — dynamic facilitators, not ontological curatives.

7. Formal proofs: desynchronization theorem, thermodynamic compatibility, impossibility of suffering for AI.

Qur'an–PTT correspondence. Mental suffering is read as a signal of misalignment — Surah al-ʿAṣr encodes the drift equation (Trelax > 0) and the four stabilization operators, including ṣabr (acceptance/patience) as the fundamental condition for realignment.

Scope. This article transforms psychiatry from a taxonomy of symptoms into a geometry of misalignments, with testable predictions, an experimental protocol (atomic clocks + biomarkers), and cross-validation through empirical pharmacology.

metadata.title: Food Fermentation and Probiotics
metadata.description:
Food Fermentation and Probiotics offers an in-depth and contemporary 
exploration of microorganisms, biochemical transformations, technological processes, 
and health-promoting attributes that define fermented foods and probiotic 
applications. Structured in four comprehensive parts, the book begins with the 
fundamentals of microbial taxonomy, ecology, and metabolic pathways that govern 
fermentation systems. It then progresses into traditional, ethnic, and industrial 
fermentation technologies, examining substrate selection, process optimization, 
starter cultures, quality attributes, and safety considerations. 
Subsequent chapters provide a rigorous treatment of probiotics, detailing their 
mechanisms of action, strain-specific functionalities, physiological benefits, and global 
regulatory frameworks. Special emphasis is placed on next-generation concepts 
including postbiotics, metabiotics, paraprobiotics, psychobiotics, synbiotics, and 
precision probiotics, supported by recent clinical evidence and translational 
research. 
The book integrates classical principles with cutting-edge advancements such as 
microbiome modulation, omics-based characterization, bioprocess engineering, 
controlled fermenters, bioactive discovery, and functional food innovation. Each 
chapter combines conceptual clarity with critical evaluation of international 
literature, case studies, industrial practices, and safety/regulatory standards 
(FAO/WHO, FSSAI, EFSA, FDA). 
Designed to meet the academic and professional needs of students, educators, 
researchers, product developers, and industry practitioners in Food Science, 
Dairy Technology, Biotechnology, Microbiology, Nutrition, and Fermentation 
Engineering, this volume serves both as a core textbook and a practical reference 
guide. It equips readers with scientific insight, analytical skills, and technological 
understanding essential for developing high-quality fermented foods, evaluating 
probiotic efficacy, and applying microbiome-based strategies in human health.
